questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with bilateral pneumonia that is caused by an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing Klebsiella. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Amoxicillin, ticarcillin

Clavulanic acid

Ampicillin, cefoperazone

Sulbactam

Piperacillin, ceftolozane

Tazobactam

Meropenem

Vaborbactam

Imipenem

Relebactam

Ceftazidime

Avibactam

questions.text: All are true about colistin except?

options.label: A
options.text: It is primarily used as a last-resort treatment for multidrug-resistant bacterial infections.

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated with potential nephrotoxic and neurotoxic side effects.

options.label: C
options.text: It is known for its efficacy against gram-negative bacteria.

options.label: D
options.text: It is primarily administered via oral route.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is primarily administered via oral route.
questions.explanation:
Colistin

Type

Polypeptide antibiotic

Pharmacokinetics
  • Administration: IV or via inhalation 
  • Distribution: Poor penetration into tissues, primarily stays in the blood
  • Metabolism: Minimal metabolism
  • Excretion: Primarily excreted unchanged in urine

Mechanism of Action

Colistin ⟶ Binds to Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) in Gram-negative Bacterial Cell Walls ⟶ Disrupts Membrane Integrity ⟶ Increases Permeability of Cell Membrane ⟶ Leakage of Intracellular Contents ⟶ Bacterial Cell Death

Uses
  • Multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacterial infections (Option C)
    • Pseudomonas
    • Acinetobacter
    • Klebsiella pneumoniae
    • Escherichia coli
  • Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
  • Catheter-associated UTI

Side Effects
  • Nephrotoxicity (Option B)
  • Neurotoxicity (paresthesias, dizziness, confusion) (Option B)
  • Respiratory depression (with systemic use)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions (rare)
  • Neuromuscular blockade (rare)
  • Superinfection (especially with prolonged use) (rare)

Special Points
  • Due to its toxicity profile and risk of resistance development, it is considered a last-line option for treating multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections (Option A).
  • Inhalation treats respiratory infections, particularly in cystic fibrosis patients with Pseudomonas aeruginosa colonisation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is admitted to the ICU for ventilator-associated pneumonia. He has been on mechanical ventilation for the past 48 hours due to respiratory failure secondary to severe sepsis. Cultures from his sputum reveal vancomycin-resistant organisms. What would be the preferred drug for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Linezolid

Type/Class

Oxazolidinone antibiotic

Pharmacokinetics
  • Administration: Oral or IV
  • Absorption: Well-absorbed orally, with bioavailability of approximately 100%
  • Distribution: Widely distributed in body tissues, including the lungs, skin, and bone
  • Metabolism: Minimal metabolism
  • Excretion: Excreted unchanged in urine

Mechanism of Action

Linezolid ⟶ Binds to the 50S Ribosomal Subunit ⟶ Inhibits Initiation of Protein Synthesis ⟶ Blocks Elongation of Peptide Chains ⟶ Inhibits Bacterial Protein Synthesis ⟶ Bacteriostatic or Bactericidal Activity.

Uses
  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
  • Vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA)
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Complicated skin and skin structure infections
  • Nosocomial pneumonia (including those caused by MRSA)

Side Effects
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Rash
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Peripheral neuropathy (with prolonged use)
  • Serotonin syndrome
  • Lactic acidosis (rare)

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, watery diarrhoea, and fever. She has a history of recent antibiotic use for a respiratory infection. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness and distension. A colonoscopy showed the presence of pseudomembranes. Based on these findings, what is the best treatment choice for this patient?

A 45-year-old male patient with a history of Staphylococcus aureus infection is being treated with antibiotics. During his treatment, he develops a sudden onset of flushing, redness of the upper body, and pruritus (itching). Which drugs are most likely responsible for the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Common

Rare
  • Nephrotoxicity (especially with prolonged use or high doses).
  • Ototoxicity (especially with rapid infusion or high doses).
  • Thrombophlebitis at IV site.
  • Neutropenia.
  • Anaphylaxis.

questions.text: All are true regarding aztreonam except?

options.label: A
options.text: Used primarily to treat Gram-negative bacterial infections.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be administered both orally and intravenously.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a low cross-reactivity with penicillins, making it suitable for patients with penicillin allergies.

options.label: D
options.text: Primarily undergoes renal excretion and requires dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment.

questions.correct_answer: B. It can be administered both orally and intravenously.
questions.explanation:
Aztreonam

Type

Monobactam Antibiotic

Pharmacokinetics
  • Absorption: Administered IV or IM 
  • Distribution: Widely distributed in the body, including CSF
  • Metabolism: Minimal metabolism
  • Excretion: Primarily excreted unchanged in urine, requires renal dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment. (Option D) 

Mechanism of Action

Aztreonam ⟶ Binds to Penicillin-Binding Proteins (PBPs) ⟶ Inhibits Peptidoglycan Cross-linking ⟶ Disruption of Bacterial Cell Wall Synthesis ⟶ Cell Lysis ⟶ Bacterial Death

 

Resistant to beta-lactamases, but susceptible to metallo-beta-lactamases and extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs).

Uses

Treatment of Gram-negative bacterial infections (e.g. Salmonella typhi, Pseudomonas), not effective against Gram-positive bacteria or Anaerobes. (Option A)

  • Urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Lower respiratory tract infections
  • Septicemia
  • Skin and skin structure infections
  • Intra-abdominal infections
  • Gynecological infections

It is particularly useful for patients allergic to penicillins or cephalosporins.

Side Effects

Common:

  • Rash
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
 

Serious:

  • Hypersensitivity reactions (anaphylaxis)
  • Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhoea
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia

Special Points
  • It can be used in patients with penicillin allergy due to low cross-reactivity, except for Ceftazidime. (Option C)
  • Often combined with beta-lactamase inhibitors (Avibactam) to expand the spectrum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient residing in Delhi presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, hypotension, and altered mental status. Blood cultures are positive for a gram-negative bacillus. The patient is diagnosed with sepsis, and subsequent laboratory testing reveals that the causative organism produces New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM-1). Given this information, which of the following is the best treatment choice?

A patient initially admitted to the intensive care unit with respiratory failure was escalated to invasive ventilation. Few days later, he developed a fever along with basal crackles and patchy consolidation can be seen in chest X-ray. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?

A patient who initially presented with symptoms of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is found to be methicillin-resistant. The report also said vancomycin would also be ineffective in this organism. Which of the following cephalosporins can most likely be used effectively in this patient?
questions.explanation:
First generation
  • ENT, upper respiratory & cutaneous infections
  • Cephazolin is the DOC for surgical site infection prophylaxis 

Second generation
  • Mixed aerobic-anaerobic infections (Only cephalosporin class effective against anaerobes)
 

Third generation
  • Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime: empirical therapy for meningitis
  • Ceftazidime: Pseudomonas meningitis
  • STI : Gonorrhea, chancroid, syphilis
  • Enteric fever
  • Patients with neutropenia

Fourth generation
  • Nosocomial infections (intensive care borne)
 

Fifth generation
  • Penicillin resistant community acquired and hospital acquired pneumonia by S.pneumoniae
  • Penicillinase producing S.aureus infections
  • MRSA

questions.text: Which of the following is a 4th generation cephalosporin?
questions.explanation:
1st gen

2nd gen

3rd gen

4th gen

5th gen

Cephazolin (Option B ruled out)

Cephalexin

Cefadroxil

Cefuroxime

Cefoxitin

Cefaclor

Cefprozil

Cefixime (Option A ruled out)

Cefotaxime

Ceftizoxime

Ceftriaxone

Ceftazidime

Cefpodoxime proxetil

Cefdinir (Option D ruled out)

Ceftibuten

Ceftamet pivoxil

Cefepime

Cefpirome (Option C)

Ceftaroline

Ceftobiprole

questions.text: All of the following drugs correctly match their mechanism of action. 1. Cycloserine a. Inhibits enzyme bactoprenol dephosphorylase 2. Fosfomycin b. Inhibits enzyme transpeptidase 3. Monobactam c. Inhibits enzyme enol pyruvate transferase 4. Bacitracin d. Inhibits enzyme alanine racemase and ligase
questions.explanation:
Cell wall synthesis inhibitors

MOA

Drugs

Uses

Side effects

Inhibits transpeptidase (penicillin-binding protein) and prevents cross-linking

Beta-lactam drugs

1. Penicillin

2. Cephalosporin

3. Carbapenems

4. Monobactam (Aztreonam)
  • MSSA infections
  • Perioperative prophylaxis
  • Syphilis
  • Meningitis
  • Community-acquired pneumonia
  • GI and GU infection
  • Aztreonam in penicillin allergy.
  • Ertapenam in ESBL, P. aeruginosa, and Acinetobacter

1. Hypersensitivity

2. Cross hypersensitivity (except monobactams)

Inhibits enol pyruvate transferase and block GAG synthesis

Fosfomycin
  • Enterococcal UTI (Foley's catheter)
  • Transurethral procedures
  • Safe in pregnancy

1. Hematuria

2. Urinary discomfort

3. Neuropsychiatric: Psychosis, seizures

D-alanine analogue inhibits alanine racemase and ligase

(Bacteriostatic)

Cycloserine
  • Multidrug resistant TB

1. Neurotoxicity

2. Psychosis

3. Depression (Suicide risk)

Inhibits bactoprenol dephosphorylase enzyme

Bacitracin
  • Topical cream in gram-positive cocci (Staphylococcus and Streptococcus) skin infection
  • Oral: Enterococcal infection

1. Nephrotoxic (IV)

2. Bone marrow suppression

Inhibition of transglucosidase enzyme

Vancomycin
  • Pseudomembranous colitis(oral)
  • MRSA
  • E. faecalis

1. Nephrotoxicity

2. Ototoxicity

3. Red man syndrome

questions.text: A patient who was admitted with suspected osteomyelitis is found to be caused by Staphylococcus aureus that shows resistance to methicillin. Which of the following is least likely to be the drug of choice for this patient?
All of the following are true regarding penicillinase-resistant penicillins except?

options.label: A
options.text: Dicloxacillin falls in this group of drugs.

options.label: B
options.text: Methicillin is preferred in patients with renal disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Not resistant to penicillinase of gram-negative bacteria.

options.label: D
options.text: Concomitant use of contraceptive pills is contraindicated with nafcillin.

questions.correct_answer: B. Methicillin is preferred in patients with renal disease.
questions.explanation:
Penicillinase-resistant penicillins

Side effects

Cloxacillin (oral)

Coagulation defect/bleeding

Oxacillin (oral)

Hepatotoxicity

Nafcillin (IV)

Neutropenia

Dicloxacillin (oral) (Option A)

Hepatotoxicity

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect about extended spectrum penicillins except?

options.label: A
options.text: Ampicillin is one of the preferred drugs of choice in typhoid fever.

options.label: B
options.text: The biliary concentration of ampicillin is low and hence not used in cholecystitis.

options.label: C
options.text: Piperacillin is more potent than carbenicillin in pseudomonas infections.

options.label: D
options.text: Carbenicillin is the preferred drug in this group in heart failure patients.

questions.correct_answer: C. Piperacillin is more potent than carbenicillin in pseudomonas infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male recently began treatment for painless lesions in his palms and soles and presented to the emergency department with fever, chills, and myalgias. These symptoms developed a few hours after receiving his first dose of benzathine penicillin G. On examination, he appears flushed (image) with tachycardia and hypotension. Based on the findings, match the most likely diagnosis and management of this condition. 1. Anaphylactic reaction A. Continue medication and start antipyretics 2. Serum Sickness B. Administer epinephrine 3. Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction C. Discontinue and switch to alternate medication 4. Steven-Johnson syndrome D. Discontinue medication and admit to ICU

A 50-year-old male presents to the hospital with headaches, difficulty coordinating his movements, and memory loss over the past six months. On physical examination, his pupils are irregular and do not constrict to light but constrict during accommodation. He had a history of painless genital ulcer, which was resolved on its own a few years ago. What is the drug of choice used for this condition in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A single dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G

options.label: B
options.text: Once weekly dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G

options.label: C
options.text: Once weekly dose of 24 million IU penicillin G

options.label: D
options.text: Continues dose of 24 million IU penicillin G

questions.correct_answer: D. Continues dose of 24 million IU penicillin G
questions.explanation:
Stages of Syphilis

Treatment

Primary syphilis

Chancre (painless genital ulcer)

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU (Option A)

Secondary syphilis

Spread in blood: Rash involving palms and soles, uveitis

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Early latent syphilis

Dormant for < 1 year

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Late latent syphilis

Dormant for > 1 year

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option B)

Tertiary syphilis

Activation after one year and damages the organs (gummas)

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option C)

Damage to heart: Cardiovascular syphilis (aortic aneurysm, arteritis)

Damage to the brain: Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis, ataxia, dementia, Argyl Robertson pupils)

Continues IV Aqueous Penicillin G 18-24 IU for 10-14 days. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding penicillins is true? Acid-stable penicillins are destroyed by gastric acid and must be administered parenterally. Penicillin G is an acid-stable penicillin that should be given in high doses if administered orally. Acid-stable penicillins are avoided with food and antacids. Acid labile penicillins include amoxicillin, ampicillin and oxacillin.
questions.explanation:
Acid Labile Penicillin

Acid Stable Penicillin
  • Penicillin G is degraded in the stomach by HCl (Statement 2)
  • Route:
    • Parenteral
    • If oral necessary: given in high doses
  • Resistant to gastric HCl (Statement 1)
  • Route: Oral
  • Drugs: Mnemonic: VODCAA
    • Penicillin V (No effect on meningococcus)
    • Oxacillin
    • Dicloxacillin, Flucloxacillin
    • Cloxacillin
    • Ampicillin
    • Amoxicillin (Statement 4)
  • Avoid food and antacids except for amoxicillin (Statement 3)
  • Given 30 mins before food or >2 hrs after food

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with a sore throat and fever for three days. Previous medical history includes breathing issues and rashes caused by an unknown medicine used to treat syphilis one year ago. A throat swab confirms the streptococcal infection. What is the best treatment option for this patient?

A 19-year-old college student arrives at the emergency room complaining of photophobia, high fever and severe headache. A physical examination reveals pain when extending the legs and stiffness on neck flexion. Following a lumbar puncture, the cerebrospinal fluid was cloudy, with high protein, low glucose and raised white blood cell count. What is the most appropriate treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Meningococcal Meningitis

Causative organism
  • Neisseria meningitidis

Treatment
  • DOC: IV Ceftriaxone (Third generation cephalosporin)

Prophylaxis
  • Adult: Ciprofloxacin (earlier Rifampicin)
    • Prevents nasal colonisation
  • Children and Pregnant women:
    • Ceftriaxone injection (as Ciprofloxacin ( FQ) causes cartilage damage in children and fetus).

questions.text: Penicillin is helpful for the treatment of all of the following conditions except?
questions.explanation:
Penicillins

Classification
  • Natural Penicillins
    • Penicillin G/Benzylpenicillin/Crystalline penicillin
      • First penicillin
      • Parenteral route only
      • Allergic potential
      • Narrow spectrum
      • Resistance exhibited by beta-lactamase enzyme-producing organisms
      •  
    • Penicillin V: Enteral route
  • Penicillinase resistant penicillin
    • Methicillin, cloxacillin, nafcillin, oxacillin, and dicloxacillin
  • Aminopenicillins: Ampicillin, amoxicillin.
  • Anti-pseudomonal penicillins: Piperacillin, ticarcillin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Poor CNS penetration (except Penicillin G and nafcillin)
  • Poor eye penetration
  • Poor prostate penetration

Uses (SMART Player GAYLE)
  • S: Syphilis: DOC for neurosyphilis (Option B ruled out)
  • M: Meningococcal meningitis
  • A: Actinomycosis
  • R: Rat bite fever: Streptobacillus, Spirillosis
  • T: Tetanus
  • Player: Pasteurella multocida
  • G: Gas gangrene (Myonecrosis): Clostridium perfringens
  • A: Anthrax
  • Y: Yaws
  • L: Leptospirosis (Option D ruled out)
  • E: Every species: Streptococcus, Staphylococcus if sensitive (Option A ruled out)
